comments.commentBody: Exactly--it is outrageous for CIA to with-hold information from the people's elected representatives.
@Steve Ky.: I beg to differ. The healthcare law is one of the few cases where we "peons" may actually get to take advantage of some the same benefits enjoyed by those in Congress. Bad example.
@Doug Karo: If that's the case, it's too little too late.

It's not so much what you describe as what Sen. Feinstein referred to - the Speech or Debate clause:

"...shall in all Cases, except Treason, Felony, and Breach of the Peace, be privileged from Arrest during their attendance at the Session of their Respective Houses, and in going to and from the same; and for any Speech or Debate in either House, they shall not be questioned in any other Place."

The general idea, as I understand it, is that to have an arm of the government such as the CIA, with its powerful intelligence apparatus, going in at will to root around congressional computers is a form of "questioning" (searching etc.) that has a side effect of intimidating members or possibly arresting them on pretexts. Just because sunshine laws exist doesn't mean the CIA has the right to go through congressional computers at will. Same as they don't have the right to wake up senators in the middle of the night on the pretext of sunshine to effectively harass them and give the impression that they're hiding something. There has to be a balance between the ultimate public-ness of these records and the dignity and process of running the government. I happen to agree that it's ironic that the government is now feeling a taste of its own medicine, but that doesn't render the Speech or Debate clause obsolete.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speech_or_Debate_Clause
@MJ: I wouldn't hold my breath on that.

There was another report that said the staff was at the CIA using CIA computers. IT turned out that the agency  found that someone had  accessed the network they were not authorized for.  Te agency checked their logs to determine who it was. They had a responsibility to find breaches in their security. If it is true, Feinstein is just blowing smoke to obscure her staff's actions.  This outrage is in conflict with her stance on the NSA monitoring our email and phone calls as well a hacking phones through games.  She acts like she is the number one fan of the NSA activities. Scary isn't it.

Miss Diane is looking for a convenient hide-site as she tries to have it both ways on the whole Snowden issue.  80 years old and going strong ... Tomorrow she will nominate Snowden as our ambassador to the Crmea.

Sen. Feinstein's exact words: "The committee’s preference was for the CIA to turn over all responsive documents to the committee’s office, as had been done in previous committee investigations."[1]

"a senator is the voice of million of people"

As a Senate Committee Chairman, she is representing all Americans.

[1] http://www.feinstein.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/press-releases?ID=db84e...

Is anything surprising here?  Feinstein has given the intelligence community free rein for years, supporting every extension of their authority despite their clear violation of the spirit of our Constitution and Bill of Rights.  And then, now she blames those agencies when they feel they can run roughshod over her and her committee?  I'm a big supporter of the IC in its foreign intelligence role.  But when they got, with her blessing, domestic authorities...well, you're reaping what you sowed, Diane.

"As the left so often likes to point out, 'If you haven't broken any laws you have nothing to worry about.'"

Huh? Who on "the left" ever says that?

Senator not so Feinstein, is sniffing the wind and is trying to get on the popular side of this issue.
She has been a cheerleader for the spy's from day one.
Americans should be able to come together on this issue.

It must be said that Rand Paul has been critical of this assault on our freedom from day one.

If the spy's need someone to attack turn them loose on the predatory corporations.
how does one find out about companies that would rent one's roof? it's a cool idea. i'm on the east coast, however. smango at mcb dot harvard dot edu. thanks.

In CA (and most of the Southwest) solar is already cheaper than the normal utilities. That's why several companies have sprung up that will 'rent' your roof and install the solar. You sign up to a 10 year electricity contract (fixed price - under current rate) and done.

Yes, it still depends on a subsidy, but (as Nancy noted) if we properly charged for fossil fuels (pollution, land damage for coal, CO2) no subsidy would be necessary.

Sure, as several curmudgeons noted, this doesn't totally get rid of fossil fuel generated electricity. But since significantly more electricity is usually used during the daylight hours, the reliance on fossil fuels goes way down, and other sources (e.g. tidal) may eventually reduce them even more.

"Being a politician is the only job where you are allowed to seek your next job ... while on the payroll of your existing job."  What nonsense!  Have you never heard of people looking for a new job before leaving the old one?

Firestone meant exactly what he said:  money, as opposed to people.  If unions can get thousands of members to work for a candidate, that's how democracy is supposed to work, not by a handful of people buying hours of TV attack ads (through secret channels, courtesy the IRS -- Republican weeping about alleged vicitmization by the IRS notwithstanding).
inkberrow really believes Trumka is figuratively fatter than David Koch!  Gee, inkeberrow, did you really see Trumka's income tax return?  Those 11-figure income entires must be a sight to behold.

NOWI say, Let's drink to these varied Humpday libations that when being proffered and pored, one has only to say...Chen!

I'm so thoroughly SNOOKERED that I'm currently on all FOURS...Hic!

Howie
Apostrophe usage challenged.

In it's current form, I think the expression that fits best is : "Well..it seemed like a good idea at the time." At it's best, it is a wellspring of instant information and knowledge that would take months or years to look up using the conventional methods. At it's worst, it is a hate-filled cesspool, inhabited by "anonymous" creeps and lonely perverts. Hopefully it will shake out some of the more serious flaws, voluntarily or by some sort of regulation. I hope for the former and dread the latter. Thank you Mr. Berners-Lee.
No.

I wonder about the corrupt portrayal by our so called leaders when it comes to water boarding, that it really is not torture but simply an interrogation technique. One can only imagine the terror felt by people who were subjected to it, the lifelong damage to emotional and very possibly to physical health.

As a child, I was taught that our nation is a shining beacon and inspiration to all around the world. Can we still say so?

Confusion indeed!
http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-03-12/malaysian-military-denies-detectin...

"Air force chief General Rodzali Daud was quoted as saying that radar had last detected the plane over the Strait of Malacca off western Malaysia, which would have indicated it veered west from its intended flight path.

But Mr Rodzali says he "did not make any such statements," and that newspaper Berita Harian published "what is clearly an inaccurate and incorrect report".

However, he says authorities have not ruled out the possibility the airliner inexplicably changed course before losing contact."

Sue, too much non-critical speculating going on. If you're up for wondering, at least consult with the experts -- whose thoughts are freely available on line -- first.  The "ringing" is of callers' phones and means nothing.  There is no evidence whatsoever of passengers' phones calling out since the time of disappearance.  Likewise, no auto-signals from plane indicating trouble at or after the time of disappearance. A water landing, controlled or not, is certainly not ruled out. But there is no comparison between loss of contact at 35K feet, over the ocean, on a moonless night and Sullenberger's aborted flight, in broad daylight, ending just a few miles from the airport where the flight originated.  "We" don't reach a conclusion, not until all the available evidence is in and expert analysts pore over the data. It's silly and/or ignorant to speak now of reaching conclusions.

I wonder if it's possible that the pilot tried to land safely on the surface of the water but then the doors became jammed, no one could open them and the plane sank, tragically enough, to the bottom of the ocean and perhaps in such a deep part that we may never know. Conspiracy theories will abound for years if we don't reach some conclusion.. However, think of Sullenberger's safe landing on the waters of the Hudson.. It's possible this pilot tried something similar but wasn't helped by any help in the vicinity and quickly sank? It seems likely in the absence of all evidence. That's why phones are still heard 'ringing' because they are locked in an air tight environment and no water damage yet.. Until the batteries run out..

Can some other agency please take over this investigation? Malaysian officials may be trying their best, but just can't deal with it.  Why is it so hard to prevent the release of inaccurate information?  I think if I were the relative of one of the missing I would get on a boat and start my own search.

At the very first press conference the Malaysian air force chief attended he mentioned that military radar had detected something in the vicinity the Straits of Malacca but it wasn't clear that it was an aircraft. The media didn't seem to pick up on this but as far as I can see the authorities have remained consistent in saying that the last confirmed signal from MH370 was in the Gulf of Thailand. The confusion seems to have come from the poor standard of reporting across both print and TV news. The only inconsistency I can recall is the initial statement that the two passengers with stolen passports were Asian in appearance. The question is, what is "Asian"? It means different things to different people.  However, it did lead to confusion between Malaysian authorities.

Didn't you read the response from the authorities the other day? They found the mother of one of the Iranians in Germany!

We all know that terrorists don't have mothers, so they were obviously good boys. Duh!

Just can't completely buy into the scenario that two known middle class migrant Iranians (oxymoron) with valid Iranian passports, who felt compelled to use stolen passports to wend their way to Europe, buying their tickets together, in Thailand, with cash, from a Mr. Ali, an Iranian in Thailand, are somehow not in any way involved. I have read the "trafficking" theory, and while this is no doubt an issue, maybe it is unrelated to these two Iranians. Just maybe!

Robert, Bezos kind as not to reveal Johns avatar until he himself does the honors.

WHH
Reality does not trace the course of your leisure reading and cherry-picking of news articles.

@Mike...you make good points. I've wondered too. Malaysia a Moslem country...pilot probably Moslem. It would be interesting to know how religious he was. Where did he go to mosque and finally, what did the Imam there preach about. China also has a Moslem insurgency and many enemies, of all stripes.

Kindly look at this piece in this very paper about the trial of Bin Laden's relative and notice the direct involvement of Malaysians in the terrorist plot under discussion there.

"At Trial of Bin Laden Relative, Witness Describes Meeting 9/11 Mastermind"

http://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/12/nyregion/at-trial-of-bin-laden-relativ...

Now tell me that it is not starting to sound like this plane was hijacked, perhaps with the complicity of some of its Malaysian crew. The crew would have deliberately turned off all radar, radios, transponders, and other communication equipment. The plane would then have been then flown to some nefarious, rogue place which is complicit in this deed. Eventually the plane would be be loaded with explosives, maybe nukes or dirty nukes, and crashed into something.

Shades of Clancy's "The Sum of All Fears"?
